channel.title: BBC News - Technology

item.title: Chip giant's IPO hit by Beijing crackdown on business
item.description: The share listing of BYD Semiconductor has been suspended due to a regulatory investigation.

item.title: Computer Space and beyond: 50 years of gaming
item.description: From an arcade game to a multi-billion pound industry, the BBC charts the ups and downs of video games.

item.title: Afghanistan: Will fingerprint data point Taliban to targets?
item.description: Campaigners worry fingerprint and iris scan data could by used by the Taliban to identify individuals.

item.title: OnlyFans porn ban a 'kick in the teeth' for creators
item.description: Content creators aren't pleased about the site's decision to ban explicit content from October.

item.title: Ryan Reynolds: Video games and the making of Free Guy
item.description: Actor and producer Ryan Reynolds on preparing to play a character caught up in a multiplayer game.

item.title: OnlyFans to ban sexually explicit content
item.description: The online subscription site will prevent users from posting content showing 'sexually explicit conduct'.

item.title: Apple delays recalling staff to the office until 2022
item.description: The decision comes as fears grow over the impact of surging Covid cases in the US.

item.title: London council worker's bus odyssey sparks Twitter storm
item.description: Jo Kibble got from London to Morecambe in a day on public buses - "a great way to see the country".

item.title: Facebook moves to protect Afghan users' accounts amid Taliban takeover
item.description: The tech giant says it wants to reassure people worried about being tracked down by the Taliban.

item.title: Hackers steal nearly $100m in Japan crypto heist
item.description: The incident comes days after $600m of cryptocurrencies was stolen from another digital platform.

item.title: Facebook reveals most-seen posts are inane questions, not politics
item.description: "Does sugar go in spaghetti?" is among the US's top posts, as Facebook battles right-wing content claims.

item.title: The NI inventor who saved thousands of lives
item.description: The plane ejector seat was invented by James Martin, from Crossgar in County Down, in 1944.

item.title: Green aviation: Electric powered plane trialled over Orkney
item.description: A hybrid-electric plane is being trialled in Orkney as part of a study into ways of reducing aviation emissions.

item.title: The zero-power sewage plant inspired by cows
item.description: Fifty sustainable sewage treatment plants have been built that work in similar way to a cow's stomach.

item.title: The $8bn EV company you’ve probably never heard of
item.description: Electric vehicle firm Arrival is worth $8bn (£5.7bn) - and is only making vans, buses and taxis.

item.title: Virtual reality: 'There's no max, there's no limit!'
item.description: "There's no max, there's no limit" to virtual reality, so is it the future of live music?

item.title: Why phone scams are so difficult to tackle
item.description: Phone fraud, both via calls and text messages, has soared during the pandemic.

item.title: How virtual reality can help to recruit and train staff
item.description: VR headsets are making a leap from fun gimmick to serious tool for firms' workforce management.

item.title: Just how hard is it to recycle a jumbo jet?
item.description: Thousands of aircraft were left on the tarmac due to Covid, and many will now be broken up for parts.

item.title: Would you let a robot lawyer defend you?
item.description: Why artificial intelligence is increasingly being used by the legal profession.

item.title: How can new technology protect outdoor workers?
item.description: Working outdoors in extreme heat can be deadly, new tech and better protection for workers could help.

item.title: Sharing apps are booming but will the kindness continue?
item.description: The pandemic sparked a surge in activity for sharing apps like Olio but has the trend run its course?
